Heading Groups

This Be a Heading Group

It removes margins from the default headings

To group headings, use the <hgroup> tag. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Perferendis illo repellat assumenda est fugit consectetur pariatur quaerat expedita quos ut architecto maiores praesentium, et? Tempora deserunt in iusto dolorum.

Inline Text Elements

<a> This is a link.
<mark> You can use the mark tag to highlight text.
<del> This line of text is meant to be treated as deleted text.
<s> This line of text is meant to be treated as no longer accurate.
<ins> This line of text is meant to be treated as an addition to the document.
<u> This line of text will render as underlined
<small> This line of text is meant to be treated as fine print.
<strong> rendered as bold text
<em> rendered as italicized text
<sup> This is superscript: 5023
<sub> This is subscript: H2O
<abbr> An abbreviation like HTML and CSS.
<>
<>

Alternate elements: Feel free to use <b> and <i> in HTML5. <b> is meant to highlight words or phrases without conveying additional importance while <i> is mostly for voice, technical terms, etc.

Lists

Definition List

Definition List Title
This is a definition list division.
Definition
An exact statement or description of the nature, scope, or meaning of something: our definition of what constitutes poetry.

Ordered List

  1. List Item 1
  2. List Item 2
    1. Nested list item A
    2. Nested list item B
  3. List Item 3

Unordered List

  • List Item 1
  • List Item 2
    • Nested list item A
    • Nested list item B
  • List Item 3

Tables

Default table

A basic HTML table with no classname added.

This is a table caption.
# Make Model Year
1 Honda Accord 2009
2 Toyota Camry 2012
3 Hyundai Elantra 2010

Striped table

To add stripes to odd rows, add the .table-striped classname to the <table> element.

# Make Model Year
1 Honda Accord 2009
2 Toyota Camry 2012
3 Hyundai Elantra 2010

Bordered table

To add horizontal and vertical borders to all cells, add the .table-bordered classname to the <table> element.

# Make Model Year
1 Honda Accord 2009
2 Toyota Camry 2012
3 Hyundai Elantra 2010

Horizontal table

To add only horizontal borders, add the .table-horizontal classname to the <table> element.

# Make Model Year
1 Honda Accord 2009
2 Toyota Camry 2012
3 Hyundai Elantra 2010

Code & Pre

Preformatted text

Preformatted text in a <pre> tag has no background color:

“Beware the Jabberwock, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun
The frumious Bandersnatch!”

Code

Code can be presented inline, like <?php bloginfo('stylesheet_url'); ?>, or within a <pre> block with a class of .code:

#container {
	float: left;
	margin: 0 -240px 0 0;
	width: 100%;
}
<!doctype html>
<html>
<head>
	<meta charset="utf-8">
	<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
	<title>Your page title</title>
</head>
<body>
	<!-- Your HTML goes here. -->
</body>
</html>

This page uses extra syntax highlighting with rainbowco.de.

Forms

Inline Forms

To create a default inline form, add the form-inline classname to any <form> element.

A compact inline form 
<form class="form-inline">
    <fieldset>
        <legend>A compact inline form</legend>

        <input type="email" placeholder="Email">
        <input type="password" placeholder="Password">

        <label for="remember"><input id="remember" type="checkbox"> Remember me</label>

        <button type="submit" class="button button-primary">Sign in</button>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Stacked Forms

To create a stacked form with input elements below the labels, add the form-stacked classname to a <form> element.

A Stacked Form 
<form class="form-stacked">
    <fieldset>
        <legend>A Stacked Form</legend>

        <label for="email">Email</label>
        <input id="email" type="email" placeholder="Email">

        <label for="password">Password</label>
        <input id="password" type="password" placeholder="Password">

        <label for="state">State</label>
        <select id="state">
            <option>AL</option>
            <option>CA</option>
            <option>IL</option>
        </select>

        <label for="remember" class="checkbox">
            <input id="remember" type="checkbox"> Remember me
        </label>

        <button type="submit" class="button button-primary">Sign in</button>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Aligned Forms

To create an aligned form, add the form-aligned classname to a <form> element alongside form. In an aligned form, the labels are right-aligned against the form input controls, but on smaller screens revert to a stacked form.

<form class="form-aligned">
    <fieldset>
        <div class="form-row">
            <label for="name">Username</label><input id="name" type="text" placeholder="Username">
        </div>

        <div class="form-row">
            <label for="password">Password</label><input id="password" type="password" placeholder="Password">
        </div>

        <div class="form-row">
            <label for="email">Email Address</label><input id="email" type="email" placeholder="Email Address">
        </div>

        <div class="form-row">
            <label for="foo">Supercalifragilistic Label</label><input id="foo" type="text" placeholder="Enter something here...">
        </div>

        <div class="form-row-checkbox">
            <label for="cb" class="form-checkbox"><input id="cb" type="checkbox"> I've read the terms and conditions</label>
        </div>

        <div class="form-controls">
            <button type="submit" class="button button-primary">Submit</button>
        </div>
    </fieldset>
</form>

Form Elements

Required

To mark a form control as required, add the required attribute.

<form>
    <input type="email" placeholder="Requires an email" required>
</form>

Disabled Inputs

To disable a form control, add the disabled attribute.

<form>
    <input type="text" placeholder="Disabled input here..." disabled>
</form>

Read-Only Inputs

To make a form input read-only, add the readonly attribute. The difference between disabled and readonly is read-only inputs are still focusable. This allows people to interact with the input and select its text, whereas disabled controls are not interactive.

<form>
    <input type="text" value="Readonly input here..." readonly>
</form>

Checkboxes and Radios

To normalize and align checkboxes and radio inputs, add the checkbox or radio classname.

<form>
    <label for="option-one" class="checkbox">
        <input id="option-one" type="checkbox" value="">
        Here's a checkbox
    </label>

    <label for="option-two" class="radio">
        <input id="option-two" type="radio" name="optionsRadios" value="option1" checked>
        Here's a radio button
    </label>

    <label for="option-three" class="radio">
        <input id="option-three" type="radio" name="optionsRadios" value="option2">
        And another radio button
    </label>
</form>
